author: diane.
title: perch\u00e9 questi lavoratori di Amazon stanno scioperando
text:
I dipendenti di Amazon si sono riuniti durante il Black Friday per denunciare le condizioni di lavoro dell'azienda e ritenere il colosso responsabile.
Mentre il Black Friday è in pieno svolgimento, i dipendenti di Amazon raggruppati attorno alla “UNI Global Union” e alla “Progressive International” hanno annunciato manifestazioni per il 29 e 30 novembre prossimi per protestare contro le condizioni di lavoro dell'azienda e i suoi vari abusi.
«Fai pagare Amazon»
Tutti i lavoratori si sono uniti attorno ad un messaggio chiaro: “ Fai pagare Amazon “. Attraverso azioni come scioperi o blocchi di magazzini, i dipendenti intendono denunciare il modo in cui l'azienda di Jeff Bezos tratta i propri dipendenti, spendendo “milioni di dollari per impedire ai lavoratori di organizzarsi” afferma Christy Hoffman, segretaria generale di UNI Global Union.
« L’incessante ricerca del profitto da parte di Amazon ha un costo per i lavoratori, l’ambiente e la democrazia »
Christy Hoffman, segretario generale di UNI Global Union
Lungi dall’essere un movimento una tantum, “Make Amazon Pay” è stato lanciato durante il Black Friday 2020, chiedendo ad Amazon di dare priorità alle persone rispetto ai profitti.
Per andare oltre
Come Amazon vuole uccidere le rivendicazioni sindacali
Una mobilitazione internazionale
Questa lotta, lungi dall’essere isolata, riunisce i lavoratori di più di 20 paesi, dagli Stati Uniti alla Germania, al Regno Unito, al Giappone e al Brasile. In India, proteste sono in corso a Nuova Delhi dove i lavoratori affermano di essere stati costretti a lavorare durante l'estate senza poter andare in bagno o bere mentre un'ondata di caldo si abbatteva sul Paese, indica il Posta internazionale.
L’Europa e la Francia non sono escluse. Mobilitati attorno ad Attac, l'Associazione per la tassazione delle transazioni finanziarie e l'azione dei cittadini, i dipendenti stanno organizzando diverse manifestazioni in diverse città francesi per chiedere migliori condizioni di lavoro e denunciare l'evasione fiscale presumibilmente praticata dall'azienda. Nel 2021 l'azienda è stata individuata da un'indagine di Bloomberg riferendo che Amazon non aveva pagato le tasse in Francia nonostante l’azienda avesse registrato quell’anno un fatturato di oltre 50 miliardi di euro.

author: Rebecca Greenberg
title: Cleaners union reaches tentative contract agreement
text:
Ena Softley has worked as a cleaner in Manhattan for nearly four decades — a job she tackles with immense pride.
“We put so much into these buildings,” said Softley, a 37-year member of 32BJ SEIU. “We were saving lives to clean these buildings.”
What You Need To Know Members of the 32BJ SEIU union had been rallying for a fair contract since negotiations began on Nov. 9th
A tentative deal was reached early Thursday morning, just four days before the current contract was set to expire
Under the tentative agreement, health insurance benefits will be maintained, premiums will increase no more than 3% each year and wages will increase $149 per week by the end of the four-year contract When Softley contracted COVID-19 in March 2020, she almost died from the virus. So when the fate of her health insurance and pension was at risk, she decided to fight.
“We took care of their buildings and it was their time to take care of us,” Softley said.
Members of the 32BJ SEIU union had been rallying for a fair contract since negotiations began on Nov. 9th. A tentative deal was reached early Thursday morning, just four days before the current contract was set to expire. Workers had planned to go on strike.
“We were very excited to reach a new four-year agreement that protects our members’ healthcare, that enhances our members’ retirement security and secures a historic wage increase for commercial office cleaners,” said Denis Johnston, executive vice president of the Commercial Cleaning Division for SEIU Local 32BJ.
Under the tentative agreement, health insurance benefits will be maintained, premiums will increase no more than 3% each year and wages will increase $149 per week by the end of the four-year contract. It also includes pension improvements and strengthened anti-discrimination protections.
“We knew, despite everything happening in the commercial office sector, that we had to deliver a very strong contract for our members,” Johnston said.
Union members said the contract proposed by management would have made union members pay for health insurance premium shares, established a permanent second-tier workforce, and cut overtime hours. Many viewed the contract as a slight after so many had worked through the pandemic.
“Our members had to put themselves and their families at risk every single day during the pandemic. They were essential workers, they weren’t able to work from home,” Johnston said.
32BJ represents 20,000 of the city’s commercial building cleaners. This tentative agreement helped the union avoid a historic strike that would’ve impacted 1,700 city buildings.
“Our members are a vital part of New York City. Our members are what make these buildings run. These buildings could not run without them and this contract is a recognition of those contributions and it’s an incredible victory,” Johnston said.
The tentative contract now needs to be officially ratified by 32BJ members, which they said should happen over the next few weeks.
